content: Singaporean singer**This article has multiple issues.** Please help **improve it** or discuss these issues on the **talk page**. *(Learn how and when to remove these messages)*This biography of a living person **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help by adding reliable sources. Contentious material about living persons that is unsourced or poorly sourced **must be removed immediately** from the article and its talk page, especially if potentially libelous. *Find sources:* "Daphne Khoo" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(June 2014)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)*An editor has determined that **sufficient sources exist** to establish the subject's notability. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Daphne Khoo" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(August 2023)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Daphne Khoo** (born 22 January 1987) better known by her stage name **Haneri** is a [Singaporean](/wiki/Singapore) singer. She was a contestant in the first season of [Singapore Idol](/wiki/Singapore_Idol), finishing up in fourth place (third runner up) during *Asian Songs* week. She was also host of Idol-on-Demand, an online programme for *Singapore Idol*. She was video-featured on Singapore youth TV station CTV. She was also one of the contestants in the television show *The Dance Floor* in the group Snaap! ## Early life Khoo was born in [Perth, Australia](/wiki/Perth,_Western_Australia), and moved to [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) when she was eight, where she lived with her family. She has an older and a younger sister. She studied in St Margarets Secondary School in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). She is also a cancer survivor. ## Professional background Daphne released her debut album in December 2007 titled "Desperate' featuring twelve tracks, one of which was contributed by Ling Jia Hao (Track 8 "Rescue"). She has released a few unofficial singles, and one for the Idol-based show, *[Shooting Stars](/wiki/Shooting_Stars_(Singaporean_TV_series))*. She was formerly the lead singer of [West Grand Boulevard](/wiki/West_Grand_Boulevard). She was a Mass Communications student at [Ngee Ann Polytechnic](/wiki/Ngee_Ann_Polytechnic)'s [School of Film and Media Studies](/wiki/School_of_Film_and_Media_Studies) where she pursued a diploma. She completed her degree in communications at [RMIT University](/wiki/RMIT_University) in 2009 in Melbourne, Australia. In 2010, she began studying Songwriting at [Berklee College of Music](/wiki/Berklee_College_of_Music) in Boston, Massachusetts and graduated with a degree in Professional Music. Daphne lived in Los Angeles until 2019 and now resides in Singapore. ## Filmography - *[Shooting Stars](/wiki/Shooting_Stars_(Singaporean_TV_series))* (2005); from [Singapore Idol](/wiki/Singapore_Idol) - *The Showdown* (2008); from [Channel 5](/wiki/Channel_5_(Singaporean_TV_channel))'s brand new local game show ## Discography ### Albums - *[Desperate](/wiki/Desperate_(Daphne_Khoo_album))* (2007) ### Singles - 2007: *Doll* - 2008: *[Desperate](/wiki/Desperate_(Daphne_Khoo_song))* - 2012: *Carry On* - 2013: Rooftops - 2014: Wonderland - 2014: Breathe - 2015: Louder ([Paul van Dyk](/wiki/Paul_van_Dyk) & [Roger Shah](/wiki/Roger_Shah) featuring Daphne Khoo) - 2015: Greatest (Songs of the Games-[2015 Southeast Asian Games](/wiki/2015_Southeast_Asian_Games)) - 2017: Burning Up - 2018: Feel Alright - 2022: Y Didn’t You Say So - Daphne Khoo at [IMDb](/wiki/IMDb_(identifier)) This article about a Singaporean musician is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e This article about a Singaporean singer is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: Daphne Khoo
